APPENDIX A. Analytical methods 

Elemental geochemistry 

For whole-rock geochemical analyses, unweathered samples were crushed in a steel jaw-

crusher and subsequently in an agate mill. Major elements were obtained by X-ray fluorescence 

(XRF) spectrometry after lithium metaborate/tetraborate fusion, carried out at the Núcleo de 

Apoio à Pesquisa Geoanalítica (NAP Geoanalítica), from the Institute of Geosciences of the 

University of São Paulo (IGc-USP), Brazil, following the methods described by Mori et al. (1999). 

Trace elements concentrations, including REE, were also obtained at NAP Geoanalítica, by 

inductively coupled mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) using a Perkin Elmer Plasma Quadrupole MS 

Elan 6100DRC (futher details in Navarro et al., 2008). 

Sm-Nd and Rb-Sr isotopes 

Sr and Nd isotopic compositions were determined using a Neptune multi-collector ICP-MS 

at Centro de Pesquisas Geocronológicas (CPGeo) from IGc-USP, Brazil. The same powders used for 

whole-rock elemental analyses were dissolved in acid, and the elements of interest were 

separated in ion-exchange columns following the procedures described by Sato et al., (1995). The 

Sr and Nd isotopic ratios were normalized to 86Sr/88Sr = 0.1194 and 146Nd/144Nd = 0.7219 isotopic 

ratios for mass fractionation correction. The NBS987 standard yielded a long-term average 

87Sr/86Sr value of 0.710239 ± 0.0000017 (2? error). The JNdi standard (Tanaka et al., 2000) 

yielded a mean 143Nd/144Nd value of 0.512102 ± 0.000002 (2? error). 

U-Pb, REE and Lu-Hf isotopes in zircon 

Grains of zircon of Paraguaçu Suite were prepared via traditional methods of 

disaggregation, magnetic and heavy liquid separation. These grains were mounted in 25 mm 

diameter epoxy discs, polished and coated with 40 µm of gold. The internal texture of the grains 

was characterized using CL imaging with a Tescan Mira3 FESEM from Microscopy and 

Microanalysis Facility, at John de Laeter Centre, Curtin University, Australia. 

U-Pb isotopic data were collected using the Sensitive High Resolution Ion Microprobe 

(SHRIMP II) also based at John de Laeter Centre. The mass filtered -O2 primary beam strength was 

among 2 and 3 nA with a 20 µm spot size. A 6-scan cycle and a mass resolution of ~5,000 were 

used during analysis (de Laeter and Kennedy, 1998; Kennedy and de Laeter, 1994). Data were 

processed using SQUID II and Isoplot 3.75 (Ludwig, 2009, 2003) with the correction of measured 

isotopic ratios for common Pb based on Stacey and Kramers (1975). Standards were located in a 

separate mount for the analysis and this mount was Au-coated at the same time as the unknowns 

mount. NBS610 glass was used to calibrate the position of the 204Pb peak. As a primary standard 

CUYZ (Curtin internal laboratory standard, 568.55 Ma) was used, and Pleišovice (Sláma et al., 



  

123 
 

2008) was used as a secondary standard. The secondary standard was within error of reported 

age (337.13 ± 0.37 Ma), yielding 332.3 ± 4.5 Ma during the session. A minimum error of 1.5% was 

assigned to the external spot-to-spot error to reflect the long-term performance of the SHRIMP. 

Trace elements and Lu-Hf isotopes and complementary U-Pb data of zircon were collected 

from the same samples analyzed in the SHRIMP, using Split-Stream Laser Ablation with 

Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry (LASS-ICP-MS) on an ASI Resolution M-50 with a 

193-nm wavelength Ar–F excimer laser with an Agilent 7700 mass spectrometer at the 

GeoHistory Facility, John de Laeter Centre, Curtin University. Laser fluency was 2J/cm-2, at a 

repetition rate of 10 Hz and spot size of 50 ?m.

ANEXO III – RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN METAMORPHIC PEAK AND 

DEFORMATION TEMPERATURE IN MIGMATITES AND GRANULITES 

AND THEIR CONSTRAIN ON EXHUMATION IN THE SOCORRO-GUAXUPÉ 

NAPPE, SE BRAZIL 

 

 

 

 

 

Manuscrito que será submetido ao periódico Journal of South American Earth Sciences 

  



  

132 
 

Relationship between metamorphic peak and deformation 

temperature in migmatites and granulites and their constrain on 

exhumation in the Socorro-Guaxupé Nappe, SE Brazil 

Rafael Gonçalves Motta a 

rafagmotta@gmail.com 

Renato Moraes b 

rmoraes@usp.br 

a Postgraduate Program of the Institute of Geosciences, University of São Paulo, 562, Rua do Lago, 
05508-080, São Paulo, Brazil 

b Institute of Geosciences, University of São Paulo, 562, Rua do Lago, 05508-080, São Paulo, Brazil 

 

ABSTRACT 

In the southeastern of Brazil, a thick section of a lower continental crust outcrops in the 

Socorro-Guaxupé Nappe, part of a neoproterozoic orogenic collage in the southernmost part of 

the Brasília Orogen. Migmatites, mostly diatexites, and granulites reached ultra-high temperature 

conditions during their metamorphic peak, around 1000 °C. However, both rocks present 

different structural patterns. Foliation in the migmatites is more scattered and present NW-SE 

direction, while the granulites is more concentrated with WNW-ESE direction. Lineation in 

migmatites is defined by feldspars and hydrate minerals, such as biotite and hornblende with 

WNW-ESE direction, whereas in granulites the lineation is marked by anhydrous minerals, such 

as pyroxenes and feldspars, and present WSW-ENE direction. The quartz c-axis fabric opening-

angle for the residuum of granulite shows the highest values (135-154°), followed by the 

leucosome of granulites (113-130°) and then leucosome of migmatites (86-97°). These implies 

that quartz c-axis fabric in granulites records two temperatures: the residuum is close to the 

metamorphic peak, between 869 and 923 °C, and another close to the temperature crystallization 

of the leucosome, between 796 and 853 °C. The migmatites record quartz c-axis fabric 

temperature between 633 and 685 °C. Therefore, the solid-state deformation in the granulites 

happened at higher temperature than the migmatites, which were in suprasolidus conditions 

during a larger temperature range (> 300 °C). Thus, when the granulites solidified, the migmatites 

still were molten, printing different deformation geometries. 

Keywords: Quartz c-axis fabric, deformation temperature, Socorro-Guaxupé Nappe 

INTRODUCTION 

Partial melting modifies rock rheology and density, leading to a generation of and 

segregation of two phases, a low density melt and a high density solid residue (Kohlstedt, 2002; 

mailto:rafagmotta@gmail.com
mailto:rmoraes@usp.br


  

133 
 

Sawyer, 1994; Vanderhaeghe, 2009). During active deformation, the melt moves by pervasive flow 

parallel to the principal finite elongation into foliation-parallel sheets, fold hinges and dilation 

sites, such as inter-boudins (Brown and Solar, 1998; Hasalová et al., 2008; Sawyer, 2001; 

Weinberg, 1999). At same time, granulite terrains develops characteristic horizontal structures 

during the metamorphic climax (Sandiford, 1989) in which melt will be allocated. 

The distinction among how and when these paralleled horizontal structures were 

generated linked to temperature-pressure paths may help to understand the structural-tectonic 

evolution of the middle and lower continental crust. With this purpose, quantitative structural 

analysis was used to constrain the relationship between metamorphism and deformation (e.g. 

Díaz Azpiroz and Fernández, 2003; Faleiros et al., 2016a; Fazio et al., 2016; Hasalová et al., 2008; 

Lister and Dornsiepen, 1982). However, when partial melting is involved, after its segregation 

from the site that it was generated, the melt moves to dilation sites and is adjusted to any space 

or structure imposed by the solid residue layers and only after temperature drops, its 

crystallization starts and a network of solid-touching crystals are developed that solid-state 

deformation might act over the crystallized leucosome. In regions where granulites and 

migmatites occur either as interlayered or pilled rocks, it brings the possibility to compare 

deformation and its kinematics along prograde and retrograde paths, investigating residues and 

respective leucosomes. Within this context, the progress made in recent years with quartz c-axis 

thermometer brings another interesting tool (Faleiros et al., 2016b; Law, 2014), which allows to 

not only compare deformation texture patterns in quartz, but also temperature along prograde 

and retrograde paths and with this, evaluate how deformation kinetics change along heating and 

cooling stages at the lower continental crust. 

In southeastern of Brazil, a medium- to high-metamorphic stack of nappes occur in the 

southernmost portion of the neoproterozoic Brasília Orogen (Campos Neto et al., 2007), 

exhibiting a diversity in migmatites, granulites and igneous bodies. Several works have 

constrained timescales, exhumation and causes of high-temperature metamorphism in the 

Brasília Southern Orogen (e.g. Campos Neto et al., 2010; Campos Neto and Caby, 2000; Coelho et 

al., 2017; Janasi, 2002; Motta and Moraes, 2017; Rocha et al., 2018, 2017; Tedeschi et al., 2017; 

Trouw et al., 2013) and, although they present robust data, none investigate if deformation 

histories of diatexites and granulites, most voluminous rocks at the base of the stack, are 

compatible. This paper combines structural and metamorphic data in order to enhance the 

understanding of deformation history of rocks formed at the lower continental crust. 

GEOLOGICAL SETTING 

During the Neoproterozoic, Sanfranciscan and Paranapanema plates collided and as a 

result, part of Gondwana continent was formed (Brito Neves et al., 2014, 1999). The collision 



  

134 
 

generated a pile of sub-horizontal nappes with a southwest-dipping tectonic wedge, and transport 

towards the east-northeast. Rocks from three different tectonic settings are recognized within 

these nappes, from WSW to ENE and bottom to top: (1) the Socorro-Guaxupé Nappe is the 

magmatic arc domain developed at the active margin of Paranapanema Plate, and includes 

granulites, assorted migmatites and intrusive bodies (2) the Andrelândia Nappe System is a 

subducted metassedimentary sequence and (3) the Carrancas and Lima Duarte Nappes represent 

a passive continental margin, related to the São Francisco continent (Campos Neto et al., 2011, 

2010; Campos Neto and Caby, 2000; Trouw et al., 2013). These nappes record the migration of the 

orogenic front towards the cratonic area, with older ages recorded by the upper nappes, in the 

west, and younger ages recorded by the lower nappes, in the east (Campos Neto et al., 2011, 2010, 

2004). 

The Socorro-Guaxupé Nappe is a thick section of the lower continental crust (~10 km) and 

is divided in three distinct units (Figure - 1): (1) a basal Granulite Unit, with mafic and felsic 

interlayered garnet granulites with hornblende, orthopyroxene and garnet-bearing leucosome, 

(2) intermediate Diatexite Unit, dominated by granite to granodiorite leucosome-bearing garnet 

and hornblende, which may present pyroxenes core, biotite schlieren and schollen of biotite or 

hornblende stromatic residue, and (3) a Metatexite Unit derived from metasedimentary rocks 

(Campos Neto and Caby, 2000, 1999). An window where Archean-Paleoproterozoic orthogneisses 

crops out and divides the Socorro-Guaxupé Nappe in two main domains: Socorro Domain, in the 

southeastern and Guaxupé Domain, in the northwestern (Campos Neto and Caby, 2000; Janasi, 

2002). This work is focused in eastern portion of Guaxupé Domain (Figure - 1). 

The high temperature metamorphic conditions lasted for 30-50 Ma, making it a long-lived 

event (Motta et al., n.d.; Rocha et al., 2018, 2017; Tedeschi et al., 2018). EPMA dating of monazite 

from diatexite unit indicates metamorphic peak was reached at 631 ± 4 Ma (Rocha et al., 2017). 

Similar ages (ca. 630-620 Ma) are recorded in charnockite and high-K calc-alkaline suites 

intrusive suites into the Socorro-Guaxupé Nappe (Basei et al., 1995; Janasi, 2002, 1999; Martins 

et al., 2009; Mora et al., 2014; Reno et al., 2009). While the Granulite Unit records initial stages of 

retrograde cooling at 622 Ma (Reno et al., 2009), the migmatites units record ages ca. 600 Ma for 

the final stages of melt crystallization (Rocha et al., 2017). 



  

135 
 

 

Figure - 1 Geological framework of the southmost parto f Brasília Orogen. The yellow polygon indicates the Guaxupé 
Domain, while the red polygon indicates the study area and the location of Figure - 2. 

METHODS 

Structural measures were performed using standard procedures involving identification 

and description of geometric and kinematic relationships among tectonic structures. Structural 

data was collected with compass and stereoplots were elaborated using the software Stereo32 

version 1.03 (Röller and Trepmann, 2011), projected into lower hemisphere Schmidt-Lambert 

equal area nets. 

Quartz c-axis orientations were measured using a universal stage in thin sections cut 

perpendicular to the foliation and parallel to the mineral lineation. Data were plotted into lower 

hemisphere Schmidt-Lambert equal area nets, also using the software Stereo32 version 1.03 

(Röller and Trepmann, 2011). 



  

136 
 

Pressure calibration of the Diatexite Unit was made to constraint the pressure achieved in 

the metamorphic peak using the barometer GASP (Holdaway, 2001) with minerals from a residual 

sample that bears garnet, sillimanite, quartz and plagioclase apart from K-feldspar and rutile. 

Mineral compositions were obtained by profiles across garnet and plagioclase with a wavelength-

dispersive spectrometry (WDS) in a JEOL JXA-8230 Hyperprobe at the Electron Microprobe 

Facility at Universidade Estadual Paulista (UNESP), Brazil, using a focused beam at 15 kV and 20 

nA with 10 µm spot size. Natural minerals were used as standards. 

STRUCTURAL GEOLOGY 

Along the study area of basal portion of the Socorro-Guaxupé Nappe, the main 

metamorphic foliation has a low to sub-horizontal dip-angle, generated by a non-coaxial 

deformation developed during the displacement of the nappes. These horizontal structures are 

quite common in high-grade metamorphic terrains (Sandiford, 1989). In the northeastern portion, 

the Socorro-Guaxupé Nappe is limited by Três Pontas-Varginha Nappe, marking the boundary 

between the magmatic arc domain and the metasedimentary sequence (Figure - 2). Their contact 

is defined by a thrust fault with significant lateral component. 

The Granulite Unit has a stromatic structure defined by composition and texture/grain 

size variations (Figure - 3A), parallel to the main foliation. Their texture is typical granoblastic, 

where quartz and feldspars present interlobate to polygonal grain boundary geometries and in 

layers with higher deformation ribbons of quartz are developed (Figure - 3B). The foliation is 

concentrated around the WNW-ESE direction and strike to NNE (Figure - 4), with average of 

N297/17°NE. 

 



  

137 
 

 

Figure - 2 Geological map of the studied area. Representative foliation (blue) and lineation (red) data are shown with their 
respective dip. The stars show the location of samples that were measured quartz c-axis open angle, this work in yellow 
and Faleiros et al. (2016b) in black. 



  

138 
 

 

Figure - 3 Banded felsic granulite, in the middle of the picture a boundin with residual mafic composition surrounding by 
leucosome. B. Granoblastic fabric with quartz ribbon in leucosome of granulite. C. Shear zone showing milonitic fabric of 
banded migmatite near to the contact between the units. D. Sillimanite-garnet milonite located near the contact between 
the Diatexite and Granulite Units. 

The absence of good outcrops is a factor that makes difficult to identify the contact 

relations between the Diatexite and Granulite Units. However, the intrusion of a charnockite body 

of the Paraguaçu Suite (Barros, 2012) (Figure - 2) and some outcrops with weathered rocks 

suggest that the contact is made by a low angle shear zone, where the leucosome was strongly 

stretched and residuum underwent for boudinage process (Figure - 3C). In this zone the rocks 

have a milonite fabric marked by decreasing of granulometry and formation of kinematic 

indicators (Figure - 3D). 



  

139 
 

 

Figure - 4 A. Poles of foliation density contour for the Diatexite Unit. B. Poles of foliation density contour for the Granulite 
Unit. 

The Diatexite Unit presents variable degree of partial melting, including schollen diatexite 

(Figure - 5A) and stromatic metatexite, with subordinate layers of mafic granulite and voluminous 

leucosome. With the increasing of melt fractions, the foliation elements gradually lose their 

preferred orientation due to flow perturbations and diatexites are then developed, marked by 

overall complex geometries of the field foliation (Figure - 5B) and the presence of abundant melt 

pockets, sometimes with boudinaged leucosome as competent layer (Figure - 5C), in which, 

sometimes, the textural aspect is of a plutonic rock (Figure - 5D). Nevertheless, field foliations can 

be tracked with overall consistency in the metatexites where the stromatic layered are parallel to 

the main foliation. In general, granoblastic fabric is recognized in the leucosome matrix with 

development of quartz ribbons (Figure - 5E). The plutonic-like pockets into diatexites also show 

deformational fabric with recrystallization of mineral rims and undulose extinction (Figure - 5F). 

This rocks exhibit more scattered and slightly different foliation direction (NW-SE) with higher 

strikes than the granulites, with average of N335/27°NE (Figure - 4). 



  

140 
 

 

Figure - 5 A.Schollen diatexite with mafic rafts. B. Schollen diatexite with random distribution of the foliation. C. Metatexite 
exhibiting leucosome forming pinch-and-swell structures. D. Huge pocket of leucosome with plutonic texture in a diatexite. 
E. Fine-coarsed granoblastic fabric with quartz ribbons defining the foliation in a leucosome of a metatexite. F. Plagioclase 
showing undolose extinction in a leucosome pocket with igneous texture. G. Mineral lineation marked by K-feldspar in a 
granulite. H. Assymetric fold showing transport to E. I. Pegmatoid aspect of the diatexite with centimetric phenocrystals of 
hornblende. 

Mineral lineation in the Granulite Unit is mainly given by orientation of pyroxenes and 

feldspars (Figure - 5G) and is concentrated in the WSW-ENE quadrants, with average of N255/7° 

(Figure - 6). In the Diatexite Unit, the mineral lineation is given by feldspars and hydrated 

minerals, such as hornblende and biotite. The directions are concentrated in the WNW-ESE 

quadrants, with average of N284/7° (Figure - 6). In both units, the kinematic indicators show 

transport to E (Figure - 5H). 



  

141 
 

 

Figure - 6 A. Lineation density contours for Diatexite Unit, showing direction WNW-ESE. B. Lineation density contours for 
Granulite Unit, showing direction WSW-ENE. 

P-T CONDITIONS OF METAMORPHIC PEAK 

Granulite Unit 

The Granulite Unit is mainly formed by felsic granulite, with acid to intermediate 

compositions. In addition, there are lenses of mafic granulite interlayered. The peak mineral 

assemblage is composed by (garnet) – orthopyroxene – clinopyroxene – K-feldspar – plagioclase 

– quartz – ilmenite, in which biotite and hornblende are the phases that replaced anhydrous 

minerals after metamorphic peak. Rarely, there are bands of pelitic granulite, with the paragenesis 

composed by rutile – sillimanite – spinel – garnet – K-feldspar – plagioclase – quartz. 

Conditions of metamorphic peak were first calculated among 890-900 °C at 11.5-14 kbar 

(Campos Neto and Caby, 2000; Del Lama et al., 1994), but higher conditions are found for felsic 

granulites varying from 940-1040 °C and 11.5-14.4 kbar (Del Lama et al., 2000; Rocha et al., 2018; 

Tedeschi, 2018). Phase equilibria model for felsic granulite showed that the melt crystallization 

must have occurred at temperatures no lower than 800 °C at pressure around 9 kbar (Motta et al., 

n.d.). Thus, the Granulite Unit achieved ultra-high temperature (UHT) conditions and the melt was 

crystallized at granulite facies. 

Diatexite Unit 

In the area of study, the Diatexite Unit is dominantly metasedimentary (Campos Neto and 

Caby, 2000; Rocha et al., 2017) and the degree of partial melting is variable, although the diatexite 



  

142 
 

are the dominant rock-type. The residual part of the migmatites consists of residual (garnet)-

biotite stromatic scholen or garnet mafic granulite. The leucosome is coarse-grained, sometimes 

pegmatite-like (Figure - 5I), and may contain euhedral peritectic garnet, hornblende, 

clinopyroxene and orthopyroxene, although the latter is scarce. There are few lenses of 

milonitized pelitic diatexite with rutile – sillimanite – garnet – K-feldspar – plagioclase – quartz 

assemblage. 

Garnet and plagioclase in the pelitic migmatite (sample RGM25) show flat major element 

distribution (Figure - 7). The dominant end-member in garnet is almandine 

(Fe2+/[Fe2++Mg+Ca+Mn]), which yielded an average of 0.59, with a discrete increase in the 

extreme edges of the grains where can reach 0.61. The same pattern, although mirrored, is 

observed in the XMg (Mg/[Fe2++Mg]) with average between 0.36 and 0.37, but the extreme edges 

may show a small decrease yielding 0.34. Grossular (Ca/[Fe2++Mg+Ca+Mn]) is depleted in the core 

(~ 0.03) and shows enrichment toward the rims (~ 0.04). Thus, the garnet cores have average 

composition of alm0.59prp0.36grs0.03sps0.02, while the garnet edges is alm0.61prp0.32grs0.04sps0.02. 

 

Figure - 7 Distribution of end-members along representative grains of garnet and plagioclase from the pelitic diatexite 
(RGM25). 

Albite (Na/[Na+Ca+K]) is the dominant end member in the plagioclase (Figure - 7). The 

average composition is An29 with a subtle tendency to be anortite-richer in the core, although the 

variation is no higher than 2. 



  

143 
 

Rocha et al. (2017) applied the compositions of coexisting garnet and orthopyroxene in 

leucosome of diatexite to estimate the P-T conditions of migmatites in the area. The peak 

conditions vary from 918-1139 °C and 10.3-13 kbar, and these rocks also underwent UHT 

metamorphic conditions. Although rutile is not present in the rock, Ti contents in zircon yielded 

temperatures of ca. 690-734 °C, and were interpreted as the record of melt crystallization (Rocha 

et al., 2017). 

Pressure calculated with the geobarometer GASP (Holdaway, 2001), for a sillimanite-

bearing sample (RGM25), yielded 10.6 kbar, using the cores composition of the pair 

garnet/plagioclase, assuming that they were in equilibrium during metamorphic peak, around 

1,000 °C. However, using the edges composition of the pair garnet/plagioclase, the geobarometer 

yielded lower pressures, ~ 5.5 kbar, assuming that the edges were in equilibrium during melting 

crystallization, around 720 °C. The temperatures of calculations were based in the results 

obtained by Rocha et al. (2017), both for metamorphic peak and partial melting crystallization. 

TEMPERATURE OF DEFORMATION 

The opening-angle of quartz c-axis fabrics (OA) is strongly temperature dependent and 

has proven to be a powerful deformation thermometer (Faleiros et al., 2016b; Kruhl, 1996; Law, 

2014). Eight samples were measured, being four from Diatexite Unit and four from Granulite Unit. 

The location of the samples is shown in the map of Figure - 2. Temperatures were calculated using 

OA thermometer equations (1), (2) and (3) from Faleiros et al. (2016b). 

T(°C) = 410.44 ln OA + 14.22 P(kbar) - 1272        (1) 

T(°C) = 6.9 OA + 48 (OA ? 87 °)         (2) 

T(°C) = 4.6 OA + 258 (OA ? 87 °)         (3) 

The Diatexite Unit set of samples was measured in thin sections composed by two 

hornblende-biotite diatexite, with peritectic garnet, clinopyroxene and hornblende (RGM18 and 

RGM23), one rutile-sillimanite-garnet diatexite (RGM25) and one hornblende-biotite metatexite 

with peritectic hornblende (RGM54). They show OA between 86 and 97 ° (Figure - 8) with 

temperatures ranging from 633 to 685 °C (Table - 1) at a fixed pressure of 5.5 kbar, estimated 

pressure obtained in GASP (see topic above), using the equation (1). 



  

144

samples for Diatexite Unit and E to H are samples for Granulite Unit. 

The Granulite Unit set of samples is composed by two leucosome of felsic granulite 

showing peak mineral assemblages with two pyroxenes, two feldspars, garnet, quartz and

vary from 113 to 135 ° (Figure - 8), yielding temperatures of 796-869 °C, using equation (1) at 

pressures of 9 kbar, pressure estimated for the partial melting crystallization in this unit (Motta 

et al., n.d.). Faleiros et al. (2016b) presented OA even higher in the same portion of the Guaxupé

Domain for residual parts of granulites (samples VAB-1, VAB-9b and VAB-19, also located into the 

map of Figure - 2), varying from 136 to 154 ° and temperatures from 872 to 923 °C (Table - 1).

DISCUSSION 

The geometry of the structures are straightly related to the action of strain fields (Merle, 

1986; Tikoff and Fossen, 1999). Structural data obtained here shows that there are differences in 

the direction of foliation and lineation between Diatexite and Granulite Units. 

The Diatexite Unit shows a more scattered foliation direction, mainly disperse in the NW-

SE quadrant, whereas the Granulite Unit has a more concentrated dispersion of foliation in the 

WNW-ESE direction. The lineation in Diatexite Unit is given by hydrated minerals and feldspars, 

with directions concentrated in the WNW-ESE quadrants, while the Granulite Unit presents the

146 
 

direction WSW-ENE made up by anhydrous minerals, mainly pyroxenes and feldspars. The offset 

in the penetrative structures suggests that the strain fields were different between the units. 

The metamorphic peak in both Granulite and Diatexite Units were achieved at similar 

conditions of UHT, ~ 1000 °C and 10-12 kbar (Motta et al., n.d.; Rocha et al., 2018, 2017). However, 

the conditions for the crystallization of the trapped melting in each unit was different; in the 

Diatexite Unit the crystallization of melt is recorded around 720 °C (Rocha et al., 2017) at 

pressures around 5.5 kbar, whereas in the Granulite Unit these conditions were 800 °C at 9.0 kbar 

(Motta et al., n.d.). 

These P–T settings are printed in the quartz fabrics. The measurements of c-axis quartz 

opening-angle in the residuum of rocks from Granulite Unit yielded temperatures near to the 

metamorphic peak, ranging from 869 to 923 °C, around 100 °C lower than observed in the 

metamorphic peak (~ 1,000 °C). The Granulite Unit also bears the highest quartz OA temperatures 

in the leucosome, 796 to 853 °C, similar temperature that is observed for the crystallization of the 

partial melting (Motta et al., n.d.). These quartz c-axis temperatures are interpreted as 

deformation temperatures, which the quartz was recrystallized, thus able to absorb a solid-state 

deformation. Therefore, there is a hiatus of 130 °C between the deformation temperature 

recorded in the residuum and in the leucosome of Granulite Unit, and a gap of 200 °C between 

metamorphic peak and the melting crystallization. 

The quartz fabric in the Diatexite Unit exhibits the lowest temperature, between 633 and 

685 °C. These temperatures also represent the recrystallization of the fabric in a solid-state 

deformation, which means that an enough amount of leucosome had been crystallized to form a 

network of solid-touching crystals. Hence, the gap between metamorphic peak and deformation 

of a crystallized fabric is near to 350 °C. 

Thus, the difference in the structural directions and the deformation temperatures show 

that the units had different deformational histories (Figure - 9). As soon as the trapped melt 

crystallized in the Granulite Unit, the deformation recorded a direction near to the E-W at a higher 

temperature and transport to ENE, around 800 °C. Through the high volume of melt in the 

Diatexite Unit, probably by the fertility of the protolith, once the metamorphic peak conditions 

were the same as the Granulite Unit, the crystallization of the melt happened at a much lower 

temperature, where the strain fields had undergone a variation producing plans with NW-SE 

directions and ESE lineation (Figure - 9). 



  

147 
 

 

Figure - 9 Structural evolution of the northeastern portion of Socorro-Guaxupé Nappe. During metamorphic peak (t1) 
structures were not record in the rock due to the high content of melt. The crystallization of melt in the Granulite Unit (t2) 
printed the foliation and the lineation marked by anhydrous minerals with transport to ENE. Foliation and lineation in the 
Diatexite Unit were recorded at lower temperature, in which the lineation is marked by hydrous minerals (t3). 

This idea is supported by the occurrence of a low angle shear zone in the contact between 

the units, where some charnockite bodies are emplaced. This shear zone was formed after the 

crystallization of the leucosome in the Granulite Unit, changing the rheology and allowing the 

Diatexite Unit, not yet crystallized, to move toward the craton in a channel-flow like movement. 

CONCLUSIONS 

Regardless of the formation and exhumation model chosen for these rocks some constrain 

about the Socorro-Guaxupé Nappe are important to the reconstruction of the tectonic framework 

of the southernmost part of Brasília: 



  

148 
 

? The Granulite and Diatexite Units show metamorphic peak at granulite facies, probably at 

widespread UHT conditions; 

? Although subtle, the geometries of the units are different, either the foliation and lineation 

are displaced, which imply different strain fields; 

? The contact among these units, in the studied area, is not transitional or gradational. There 

is a low angle shear zone that, even, charnockite body are intruded; 

? The deformation temperature in the residuum of the Granulite Unit is near to its 

metamorphic peak; 

? There is a gap, around 200 °C, between the temperature of the metamorphic peak and the 

temperature of deformation in the Granulite Unit and a gap of 350 °C in the Diatexite Unit.
